sn22.152:4.2: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:
sn22.152:4.3: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable’?”
sn22.152:4.4: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”
sn22.152:4.5: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:
sn22.152:4.6: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable.’
sn22.152:4.10: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:
sn22.152:4.11: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable.’
sn22.152:5.1: What do you think, mendicants? Is form permanent or impermanent?”
sn22.152:5.3: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn22.152:5.5: “But without grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
sn22.152:5.6: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable’?”
sn22.152:5.13: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn22.152:5.15: “But without grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
sn22.152:5.16: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable’?”
sn22.152:5.19: They understand: ‘… there is no return to any state of existence.’”
